raw_text:
Labour's election love-in
 
 Peace and love have been in short supply in the Labour party in recent days.
 
 If press reports are to be believed, Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown have been at each other's throats over the contents of Labour's next election manifesto. But the pair were all smiles on Tuesday morning, as they joined John Prescott to unveil Labour's latest poster campaign. The event - at Old Billingsgate Fish Market on the banks of the Thames - was a carefully choreographed show of unity. And the surest sign yet that we are heading for a general election in the next few months. It was also one of the most bizarre photo opportunities of recent years.
 
 The first inkling something slightly odd was afoot was when - in place of the soft rock music normally chosen for such occasions - Labour's speakers crackled to life with the sound of Booker T and the MGs. Then a VW camper van trundled into view, decked out in that most mind-bending of psychedelic messages - "lowest mortgage rate for 40 years". As the side-door slid open, it looked for one glorious moment as if the Cabinet had decided to bury their differences and go on the road together, Scooby Doo-style. But, sadly, it wasn't the Cabinet who had raided the dressing-up box - just six rather ill-at-ease looking Labour students. Two were dressed as Regency dandies - to unveil a poster trumpeting "the longest period of economic growth for 200 years". Another pair of students were in a Beatle wig and Sgt Pepper jacket to highlight the "lowest interest rates since the 1960s".
 
 The remaining two were dressed in a vague approximation of disco chic to demonstrate the "lowest unemployment since the seventies".
 
 The politicians - led out by John Prescott - were soberly-suited as always. The event may have been designed to highlight Labour's economic success under Mr Brown, but there was little doubt who was in charge. The chancellor walked side-by-side with Mr Milburn, pointedly exchanging chit chat, as they approached the microphone. But it was Mr Milburn who took centre stage, speaking of the "positive campaign" the party hoped to stage in the "coming weeks and months".
 
 The mobile poster vans would "let people know Britain is working again". Mr Brown repeated the familiar mantras displayed on the posters and spoke of Labour's "shared purpose" and "united dedication". It was left to Mr Prescott to pay glowing tribute to the chancellor's record and, in a final flourish, to produce his famous pledge card, from 1997, claiming Labour has met all of its promises. The event was carefully stage-managed to underline Cabinet unity. And, more specifically, to demonstrate the "central role" Mr Brown will play in the election campaign, despite being sidelined as campaign chief in favour of Mr Milburn.
 
 But keen students of body language will have had a field day. There was much forced smiling for the cameras, but only Mr Prescott, who revels in such occasions, seemed to be truly enjoying himself. Mr Milburn made a point of turning to face the chancellor, as he spoke, nodding thoughtfully. But it was the former health secretary's final gesture, placing an arm on Mr Brown's back as they walked away from the microphones, which was perhaps the most telling. Thanks for dropping by Gordon, he might have been saying.
llama3.2:1b: Labour's election campaign team unveiled a poster campaign at Old Billingsgate Fish Market, featuring speakers and posters with messages such as "lowest mortgage rate for 40 years" and "longest period of economic growth for 200 years". The event was seen as a display of unity, but sources suggest that behind the scenes, Labour's leaders had been arguing over the manifesto's content.
llama3.2:3b: Labour party leaders Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown appeared to bury their differences at a poster campaign launch in London, with a show of unity despite reports of tension over the election manifesto. The event featured Labour students dressed in psychedelic and disco outfits, accompanied by music from Booker T and the MGs. Politicians including John Prescott took part in the launch, with Milburn highlighting Labour's "positive campaign" and Brown repeating familiar slogans. The event was carefully choreographed to demonstrate unity, but subtle body language suggested a power struggle between Brown and Milburn.
gemma2:2b: Labour party members staged a photo opportunity at the Old Billingsgate Fish Market to unveil their election posters and demonstrate unity. The event included quirky student actors dressed in various costumes that highlighted Labour's economic policies.  Chancellor Brown joined Milburn on stage and exchanged pleasantries, but it was clear that Brown's political role remains key.  The event was designed to highlight the party's economic success under Mr. Brown's leadership despite not being the main campaign head.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Labour leaders Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown are celebrating a joint event to unveil a new campaign poster at Old Billingsgate Fish Market. John Prescott also joins them. The event is about unity. But Mr Brown was more focused on the party's economic achievements than on voting, and he seemed pleased when they left.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown argued over Labour's manifesto in a bizarre election rally, but ultimately decided to work together to prepare posters promoting economic success under Brown while making him look good as campaign chief.
qwen2.5:3b: Labour's election campaign has shown signs of unity, with Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown appearing at a joint event to unveil posters highlighting Labour’s economic success under John Prescott. The event featured unconventional and eclectic poster designs created by six students dressed in various era-specific costumes. Despite the apparent show of unity, there were hints of lingering tensions between Milburn and Brown, particularly through Milburn's positioning alongside Prescott. The stage-managed nature of the event underscored Prescott’s central role in the campaign while subtly placing Brown in a supporting position.

Labour's election love-in was a colorful event that highlighted the clash between Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown over Labour's next election manifesto. The launch of their latest campaign at Old Billingsgate Fish Market featured a mixtape-style music with students dressed in various odd ways to represent different policies, such as Regency dandies for economic growth,Beatle wigs for low interest rates, and Sgt Pepper jackets for unemployment. Meanwhile, John Prescott led the politicians, exchanging lines on the mic while Milburn took the lead, discussing a campaign plan aimed at "let people know Britain is working again." The event showcased Cabinet unity with students smiling and highlighted the shared purpose of Labour under Brown, even as he didn't make a big impression.
tinyllama:1.1b:
The following is a summary of the key ideas and details presented in the text:

1. Labour's election love-in: On Tuesday morning, Labour announced its latest poster campaign, with the party's leaders presenting a photo opportunity as they joined party leader John Prescott to unveil a series of posters aimed at promoting unity ahead of the general election in the next few months. The event was staged as part of a coordinated show of unity.

2. Labour's central role: Despite being sidelined as campaign chief in favour of Alan Milburn, there were forced smiles on all sides during the photo opportunity. However, keen students of body language would have appreciated the forced smiling, with Mr Prescott making a point of turning to face the chaçelle who was sitting beside him at the microphone, nodding thoughtfully.

3. Poster vans: The mobile poster van fleet displayed a mix of past Labour Party posters and new ones aimed at promoting the party's economic success in recent years. Mr Milburn continued to speak about Labour's shared purpose while wearing a Chianti red jacket, while Mr Prescott paid tribute to the party's previous manifesto by displaying his famous "pledgé" card from 1997.

4. Central role: Mr Milburn emphasised that Cabinet unity would be essential in promoting Labour's economic success before the election campaign began, while Mr Prescott delivered a plea for people to know about Labour's record and share the party's "positive campaign".

5. Camera shots: The event was carefully stage-managed to underline Cabinet unity, with each side displaying their preferred poses in front of the camera. However, there were moments where keen students of body language would have appreciated forced smiles more.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Labour party's election campaign received a lot of attention with a surprisingly light-hearted photo shoot that took place at Old Billingsgate Fish Market. The event involved several key politicians dressing up as unlikely costumes - like a disco chic student and a Regency dandy. However, the more notable inclusion was a VW camper van adorned with the message "lowest mortgage rate for 40 years". This may have been an attempt to unite the politicians under one banner, while also highlighting their shared vision of Britain's economic success.
phi:2.7b: Labour party leaders Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown have joined forces to present their latest poster campaign at Old Billingsgate Fish Market in London. The event is meant to showcase Labour's unity and economic success under Mr Brown. Despite being sidelined as campaign chief, Mr Brown will play a central role in the election campaign. However, there were some awkward moments, such as when six students dressed up to unveil posters on unemployment and mortgage rates. Overall, the event was carefully choreographed to demonstrate Cabinet unity.
orca-mini:3b: Labour's election love-in featured a poster campaign unveiling at Old Billingsgate Fish Market on the banks of the Thames, where six ill-at-ease looking Labour students dressed as Regency dandies, Beatle wigged Sgt Pepper jacket wearers and vague approximation of disco chic wearers to highlight the "lowest unemployment since the seventies", "lowest interest rates since the 1960s" and "lowest mortgage rate for 40 years" messages. The event was a carefully choreographed show of unity, with Labour's speakers crackling to life with the sound of Booker T and the MGs, John Prescott unveiling the longest period of economic growth for 200 years poster, the Chancellor walking side-by-side with Gordon Brown, Alan Milburn, and Gordon Brown in a Beatle wig and Sgt Pepper jacket. Afterwards, a pledge card from 1997 was produced by John Prescott to prove Labour has met all of its promises.
hermes3:3b: Labour party unveiling poster campaign to show unity before possible election, despite reported conflicts between politicians.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Labour party members Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown appeared united during a poster campaign unveiling at Old Billingsgate Fish Market on the Thames River, suggesting a general election is imminent. The event featured six ill-at-ease looking Labour students dressed in various themes to promote Labour's economic achievements. John Prescott led the politicians, emphasizing Cabinet unity and highlighting Gordon Brown's central role in the upcoming election campaign.

At an event in London, the two, along with John Prescott, unveiled a new poster campaign emphasizing Labour's economic achievements. The event featured an unusual spectacle, including a VW camper van and students dressed in period costumes to highlight economic milestones. While Brown and Milburn appeared together, Milburn took center stage, emphasizing a "positive campaign." Prescott praised Brown’s record, reinforcing his role in the election despite being sidelined as campaign chief. Despite the display of unity, body language suggested underlying tensions, with Milburn’s final gesture towards Brown hinting at a subtle power dynamic.
stablelm2:1.6b: During a carefully choreographed event at Old Billingsgate Fish Market, Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown held hands and unveiled Labour's latest poster campaign to signal unity before a possible general election in the next few months. The event featured various dressed-up Labour students highlighting key economic achievements under Mr. Brown's leadership. Despite Alan Milburn taking center stage as campaign chief for Mr. Brown, John Prescott paid tribute to the chancellor's record. Key takeaways are that the Labour party emphasizes unity and economic success in its election campaign, while former health secretary Alan Milburn appears to be leading the charge.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Labour politicians, including Alan Milburn and Gordon Brown, appeared united at a campaign event in Old Billingsgate Fish Market, London, on Tuesday. Despite recent tensions over the election manifesto, they unveiled Labour's latest poster campaign, emphasizing economic achievements such as low mortgage rates, historically low interest rates, and record-low unemployment. The event was meticulously staged to showcase Cabinet harmony, with John Prescott playing the role of a cheerful host. Despite some forced smiles, key body language indicators suggested that Milburn and Brown maintained a professional relationship. The chancellor's final gesture, placing an arm on Milburn's back, hinted at their ongoing collaboration. This event signaled Labour's readiness for a general election, with Gordon Brown expected to play a crucial role in the campaign despite being deputized by Milburn as the campaign chief.
